s.text: If you write anything you want me to read, please make a personal reply and allow for two weeks before I can read it.
And I hope that saying that my language is French will make the ideas in a difficult to write text even more convincing, despite being short.
Will ISO 10646 be used by OSI 6?
It will get void when a system will use the interchange code for itself.
The important thing is that the new layer be known and used.

Some intermediate compromises will have to be used like additional encoding on pathes some insist to not even try to convert to 8-bit, asking the rest of the networks to convert to 7-bit instead and to rewrite all their programs to use a complicated method for sending plain text when the sole problem is that it contains 8-bit data.

Some intermediate compromises will have to be used like additional encoding on pathes some insist to not even try to convert to 8-bit, asking the rest of the networks to convert to 7-bit instead and to rewrite all their programs to use a complicated method for sending plain text when the sole problem is that it contains 8-bit data.
But that's not sure, like for XDR which can be used from many levels to convert CPU data to line format.
On any protocol the same way, even during dialog with computer Ti using the same code ("One need not know which kind of system one is sending mail to").
What computer Si has to do to abide by the external representation is the sole matter of computer Si: to appear to others as if it were using it internally.
It is best for a computer to use the code of interchange internally, but all computers in the world cannot be modified overnight.
They have been put to use in the field of 8-bit characters.

Some intermediate compromises will have to be used like additional encoding on pathes some insist to not even try to convert to 8-bit, asking the rest of the networks to convert to 7-bit instead and to rewrite all their programs to use a complicated method for sending plain text when the sole problem is that it contains 8-bit data.
Now that the international character code ISO 10646 is out, isn't it time for communication systems to be able to not only exchange pictures and sound but also plain text?
What seems clear in my mind is that the translation is not in several final protocols, but a protocol by itself -- like XDR -- that other protocols refer to.
What seems clear in my mind is that the translation is not in several final protocols, but a protocol by itself -- like XDR -- that other protocols refer to.
What seems clear in my mind is that the translation is not in several final protocols, but a protocol by itself -- like XDR -- that other protocols refer to.
What seems clear in my mind is that the translation is not in several final protocols, but a protocol by itself -- like XDR -- that other protocols refer to.
What seems clear in my mind is that the translation is not in several final protocols, but a protocol by itself -- like XDR -- that other protocols refer to.

The _most_important_point_ is that a single common representation code be defined _for_the_line_ (suiting the purpose, namely to cover all national languages in one single way) and that people be instructed that every bit of text should travel in that code on the wire, whatever_the_protocol_is.
Many generous people have spent much time to have system Si with character code Ci translate data for system Sj with code Cj under protocol Pk.
I have learned with much interest that people envision solutions for international characters data exchange with a wider point of view than usually heard in the networking sphere.
Every piece working towards a common well defined goal finally pays more when all parts start to clutch than wandering for immediate interest.
The M*N**2 order of magnitude reduces to N. This is the extended "ASCII culture" of some future, no doubt.
While file structure (including file name etc...

docno="lists-003-2205935" received="Fri Jul 9 09:47:54 1993 EST" sent="Fri, 09 Jul 1993 18:25:04 +0200" name="Andr'e PIRARD" email="PIRARD@vm1.ulg.ac.be" subject="Thoughts about characters transmission" id="01H0C1LQB78Y8WWAUK@INNOSOFT.COM" inreplyto="Tue, 6 Jul 93 20:10 GMT"
Should we merge "presentation" and "representation" layers, split level 6 like level 2 or not assign it to any level, I'll leave the discussion to the theoricians.
It probably belongs between level 6 and 7, as it could prove that the application layer provides all the textual data.
Should we merge "presentation" and "representation" layers, split level 6 like level 2 or not assign it to any level, I'll leave the discussion to the theoricians.
Note that the "level 6 or so" concept applied to text extends slightly beyond the representation of characters (and binary data) towards file structure.
Should we merge "presentation" and "representation" layers, split level 6 like level 2 or not assign it to any level, I'll leave the discussion to the theoricians.
But that's not sure, like for XDR which can be used from many levels to convert CPU data to line format.

More theoretically said this time, this local-code to exchange-code translation works much a la OSI layer (or "a` la", if you don't mind :-) Data is encoded towards a lower layer, exchanged, and decoded back to same level, but possibly to a different local code.
It probably belongs between level 6 and 7, as it could prove that the application layer provides all the textual data.

Now that networking reaches its real dimension of an international mesh, the problem of national languages usage becomes very real, at least locally, but more and more internationally.
